## This Study

### Aim
Systematic comparison of algorithms harnessing NLP on their **capabilities and limitations in diagnosing state-specific mechanisms** influencing people when making decisions
<br>
<br>

### Research Question
How reliably can we **identify state-specific mechanisms from natural language** influencing people in decision-making?

# Possible Future Research

## The Privacy-Convenience-Paradox

- privacy calculus = (formal) theory on mental cost-benefit-analysis for sharing private information 

<span class = "source-p">@dinevExtendedPrivacyCalculus2006, @bekeConsumersPrivacyCalculus2022</span>
- privacy-convenience-paradox = preference and actual behavior are different from each other <span class="source-p"> @ackermanPrivacyEcommerceExamining1999, @zhangPrivacyVsConvenience2024 </span>
  
  $\Rightarrow$ Privacy-Calculus theory cannot explain privacy-convenience-paradox

- Decision-research: Humans do not act rational <span class="source-p">@arkesHowBadIncoherence2016 </span>

  $\rightarrow$ Bounded Rationality <span class="source-p">@simonBehavioralModelRational1955 </span>

  $\rightarrow$ Dual-Process Theory <span class="source-p">@stanovichIndividualDifferencesReasoning2000, @kahnemanThinkingFastSlow2011 </span>

## Research Question

(How) can we explain discrepancies between preference and behavior in online disclosure of private data through theories of bounded rationality and heuristics targeting the fast systems of dual-process systems?

## Hypotheses

H1: The preference-behavior discrepancy is higher when information complexity (IC) is high.

H2: The preference-behavior discrepancy is higher when the ease of withdrawing (EW) consent is low.

H3: Information complexity and the ease of withdrawing consent are interdependent moderators of the preference-behavior discrepancy.
